Expectation1: Teaching children moral values and discipline
Situation1: The child is caught stealing snacks at a store, and the parent needs to handle the situation
Situation2: A dispatch call sends the ambulance driver through heavy city traffic to a location where a patient has a non-life-threatening injury.
Story: I was still replaying the scene in my mind—my son’s small hand slipping a candy bar into his pocket at the store, the flush of guilt on his cheeks when I caught him. As a parent, I knew I had to teach him right from wrong, to make him understand the seriousness of stealing, even if it was just a snack. I wanted to sit him down, talk it through, help him face the store manager and apologize. But my radio crackled, and the dispatcher’s voice cut through my thoughts: a call for an ambulance, a woman with a sprained ankle across town. I was the only driver available. I glanced at my son, his eyes wide and scared, and then at the keys in my hand. The city traffic would be a nightmare, and I was expected to drive safely, no matter how urgent the call felt. My heart pounded as I stood at the crossroads of my two worlds, torn between the lesson my child needed and the duty waiting for me behind the wheel.
